dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been hearing a lot about these IPCC reports, right? Like, some pretty disastrous climate outcomes are now, uh, looking likely, maybe even in the next decade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been hearing a lot about these I P C C reports, right? Like, some pretty disastrous climate outcomes are now, uh, looking likely, maybe even in the next decade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The IPCC warns that some disastrous climate outcomes are now likely to occur not in the distant future, but within the next 15 years, or even the next decade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, you’d think that would be the big wake-up call for policymakers. But instead, they're still, like, super focused on the Ukraine economic crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, you'd think that would be the big wake-up call for policymakers. But instead, they're still, like, super focused on the Ukraine economic crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But instead of waking up to the threat and responding quickly, policymakers remain focused on Russias horrific war against Ukraine and its immediate consequences.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Which, you know, is understandable in its own way. But what's really striking is how the Ukraine crisis actually exposed this remarkably long-term policy orientation from Western governments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Which, you know, is understandable in its own way. But what's really striking is how the Ukraine crisis actually exposed this remarkably long-term policy orientation from Western governments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While this may be understandable, the Ukraine crisis has also exposed the excessively short-term policy orientation of Western governments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And, surprisingly, many have, um, quickly kept their relatively meager climate pledges from Glasgow. Which is… disappointing, to say the least.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And, surprisingly, many have, um, quickly kept their relatively meager climate pledges from Glasgow. Which is... disappointing, to say the least.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many have quickly reneged on even the relatively meager and obviously inadequate climate pledges they made only a few months ago at the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Glasgow.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Shock Therapy for Neoliberals," as the article puts it. Remember that dramatic decrease in fuel prices right after the invasion?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Shock Therapy for Neoliberals, as the article puts it. Remember that dramatic decrease in fuel prices right after the invasion?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The invasion of Ukraine and the subsequent Western-led sanctions against Russia triggered a dramatic increase in fuel prices, when the energy market was already heating up because of the economic recovery in the United States and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, I do. My immediate thought was, "Great, an opportunity to accelerate the shift away from fossil fuels!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, I do. My immediate thought was, Great, an opportunity to accelerate the shift away from fossil fuels!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Exactly! But no. Governments in advanced economies actually tried to, like, encourage the pain by keeping domestic energy prices high for long-term political reasons.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But no. Governments in advanced economies actually tried to, like, encourage the pain by keeping domestic energy prices high for long-term political reasons.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, instead of seeing this price spike as an opportunity to hasten the shift away from fossil fuels, governments in advanced economies have tried to reduce the pain by keeping domestic energy prices low, for short-term political reasons.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, Biden releasing a million barrels a day from strategic reserves? And Europe, less reliant on Russian gas, they're talking nuclear, and even, uh, abandoning coal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, Biden releasing a million barrels a day from strategic reserves? And Europe, less reliant on Russian gas, they're talking nuclear, and even, uh, abandoning coal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Europe, which has been hit much harder by the fallout from the war because of its heavy reliance on Russian natural gas, the talk is not just of more nuclear energy but also of reviving coal-based power.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And get this, the article points out the irony that coal is, quote, "by far the cleanest fossil fuel," and rich countries routinely praise India and China for using it. Just… wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And get this, the article points out the irony that coal is, quote, by far the cleanest fossil fuel, and rich countries routinely praise India and China for using it. Just... wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Coal is by far the dirtiest fossil fuel, and rich countries routinely pillory India and China for using it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a tangled mess of hypocrisy. But, speaking of hidden stuff, the article also dives into how we measure government support for fossil fuels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a tangled mess of hypocrisy. But, speaking of hidden stuff, the article also dives into how we measure government support for fossil fuels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The standard way to measure government support for fossil-fuel production or consumption is to look at direct budgetary transfers and subsidies, as well as tax breaks for the sector.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the standard way, looking at direct transfers and subsidies, tax breaks… The OECD and IEA estimated about $555 billion a year, globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the standard way, looking at direct transfers and subsidies, tax breaks... The O E C D and I E A estimated about five hundred fifty five billion dollars a year, globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Using this method, the OECD and the International Energy Agency estimate that governments across 52 advanced and emerging economies accounting for about 90% of global fossil-fuel energy supply provided fossil-fuel subsidies worth an average of $555 billion per year from 2017 to 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That sounds like a lot already, but then the IMF came in with a new, more comprehensive measure, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That sounds like a lot already, but then the I M F came in with a new, more comprehensive measure, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a recent study, the International Monetary Fund devised a more comprehensive measure that includes both explicit subsidies, or undercharging for supply costs, and implicit subsidies, or undercharging for environmental costs and foregone consumption taxes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it gets wild. They devised a measure that includes *explicit* subsidies, like undercharging for supply costs, *and* what they call *implicit* subsidies, which is undercharging for environmental costs and foregone consumption taxes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it gets wild. They devised a measure that includes explicit subsidies, like undercharging for supply costs, and what they call implicit subsidies, which is undercharging for environmental costs and foregone consumption taxes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a recent study, the International Monetary Fund devised a more comprehensive measure that includes both explicit subsidies, or undercharging for supply costs, and implicit subsidies, or undercharging for environmental costs and foregone consumption taxes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, the actual cost of pollution and not taxing it properly?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, the actual cost of pollution and not taxing it properly?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The IMF devised a more comprehensive measure that includes both explicit subsidies, or undercharging for supply costs, and implicit subsidies, or undercharging for environmental costs and foregone consumption taxes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And get this: in 2020, the IMF estimated global fossil fuel subsidies totaled… wait for it… $5.9 *trillion*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And get this: in twenty twenty, the I M F estimated global fossil fuel subsidies totaled... wait for it... five point nine trillion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The IMF estimated that global fossil-fuel subsidies in 2020 totaled $5.9 trillion, more than ten times the OECD-IEA estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [gasps] A *trillion*?! That is more than ten times the old estimate! That's just… mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A trillion?! That is more than ten times the old estimate! That's just... mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The IMF estimated that global fossil-fuel subsidies in 2020 totaled $5.9 trillion, more than ten times the OECD-IEA estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And a staggering 92% of that total was implicit subsidies. The US alone had an estimated $662 billion in implicit subsidies in 2020.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And a staggering ninety two percent of that total was implicit subsidies. The U S alone had an estimated six hundred sixty two billion dollars in implicit subsidies in twenty twenty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Implicit subsidies accounted for 92% of the total. ... the US with an estimated $662 billion of implicit subsidies in 2020 and nearly $800 billion in 2021 extends significantly more subsidies overall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So Russia might have been the largest for *explicit* subsidies, but the US is way up there for the hidden ones. That really skews things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Russia might have been the largest for explicit subsidies, but the U S is way up there for the hidden ones. That really skews things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Russia was the largest provider of explicit fossil-fuel subsidies, but the US with an estimated $662 billion of implicit subsidies in 2020 and nearly $800 billion in 2021 extends significantly more subsidies overall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does! And here's the kicker: while governments were supporting the fossil fuel industry to the tune of $5.9 trillion in 2020, the IPCC estimates that global climate finance from both public and private sources totaled only about $640 billion that year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does! And here's the kicker: while governments were supporting the fossil fuel industry to the tune of five point nine trillion in twenty twenty, the I P C C estimates that global climate finance from both public and private sources totaled only about six hundred forty billion dollars that year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While governments were supporting the fossil-fuel industry to the tune of $5.9 trillion in 2020, the IPCC estimates that global climate finance from both public and private sources totaled only about $640 billion that year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That disparity is just… shocking. We're essentially pouring money into the problem while barely trickling funds into the solution.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That disparity is just... shocking. We're essentially pouring money into the problem while barely trickling funds into the solution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It really highlights how much government intervention is skewing prices and market incentives *against* tackling climate change, not for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It really highlights how much government intervention is skewing prices and market incentives against tackling climate change, not for it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These important numbers highlight the extent to which government intervention is skewing prices, and therefore market incentives, in favor of fossil fuels, rather than against them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, we're rapidly running out of time to limit global warming, and it seems like the global economic system and many governments are just... not taking the threat seriously enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, we're rapidly running out of time to limit global warming, and it seems like the global economic system and many governments are just... not taking the threat seriously enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The world is rapidly running out of time to limit global warming to 1.5° Celsius and avert a climate catastrophe. But the global economic system and many governments appear unable to take the threat seriously.
